info.name: Octopus API
info.description: ## Quick Start ##### Step 1: Fork the collection using the "Run in Postman" button ##### Step 2: Make your first API call against the read-only playground You can start making API calls against the read-only demo playground. The environment is already configured. ##### Step 3: Make your API call against your Maximizer CRM instance Before making API calls against your Maximizer CRM instance, you should decide what integrations you want to create. It will help you understand what type of access you need. ## Getting API Access To start playing with API, we are providing you with two options. Choose any you want to use. #### Access with your Personal Access Token (PAT) PAT is a great start for creation integrations where you do not depend on specific users. For instance, if you need to export or move data. To create a Personal Access Token, please read the documentation here: .... #### Access with your login and password To create an integration based on user permissions and roles, you must request AppKey and VendorId. To do so, please send us an e-mail to [api@maximizer.com](mailto:api@maximizer.com) with subject "Request Appkey and VendorId" with the following details: - Full Name; - Email address; - Organization name; - Database alias; After receiving AppKey and VendorId, you can use the system method "authenticate."

exec: console.log("The Database environment variable is required.");
console.log("The UID environment variable is required.");
console.log("The Password environment variable is required.");

body.raw:
{
	database: "{{Database}}",
	uid: "{{UID}}",
	password: "{{Password}}",
	vendorId: "{{VendorId}}",
	appKey: "{{AppKey}}"
}

request.description: Use the `GetSessionInfo` method to retrieve information about the current user and Address Book database based on the token supplied in the request.

Use the `GetSystemInfo` method to get information about the system, including the current API version and the versions of API components.

NOTE: The `GetSystemInfo` method is un-authenticated, so you don't need to supply a token when calling it.

Use the `GetSystemInfo` method to get information about the system, including the current API version and the versions of API components.

exec: console.log("The Token environment variable is required.");
// This script checks to see if there is a valid token in
// the environment before making any requests to the API
// by calling the TokenValid method. If there is already a
// valid token, it does nothing. If there is no token or if
// the token is not valid, it attempts to obtain a new one
// by calling the Authenticate method, and if successful,
// saves the token to the environment.
// 2023-03-01, accept both cloud and specific url
// Get the API URL and check to make sure it is non-empty
console.error("The BaseURL environment variable is not set.");
// If we are calling the Authenticate, TokenValid, or GetSystemInfo
// methods, we don't need a valid token and can skip the rest
// Check to see if there is already a Token in the environment variable
// If there is a Token, see if it is still valid
// If there is no Token, just call Authenticate
// do nothing, PAT is aways good!
// just set PAT as Token, so we don;t have to change all collections
// (if not, we can't do anything about it)
console.info("Checking to see if token is valid...");
// Send the TokenValid request to the API
// Handles the TokenValid method response, and calls the
// Something went wrong when trying to call the API
console.error("An error occurred when trying to call the TokenValid method.");
// Check to see if the method was successful
// The token is not valid, so we will try to get a new one.
console.info("Token is missing or invalid; requesting a new one...");
// Check to see if the VendorId and AppKey are set, and if
// they are, add them to the request.
// Send the Authenticate request to the API
// Handles the Authenticate method response and stores the
// new token in the "Token" environment variable.
console.error("An error occurred when trying to call the Authenticate method.");
// Store the new token in the environment variable
// so that we can use it in subsequent requests
// A nonzero Code means that there was an error
console.error("Authentication failed. Check the credentials in the environment.");
